2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.

While Alexander White enjoyed watching the game at their favorite pub, The Crooked Billet, on May 14th, 2015, at 6:00 PM, they would have preferred if more friends were present. On May 15th, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Alexander White joined William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker for a relaxing outing at Victoria Park. That same day, the group is deciding where to watch the Luxembourg versus Israel game.
          Possible Options: Alexander White can participate in the decision of where to watch the Luxembourg versus Israel game.
          Alexander White's Goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet to the group.

        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion or suggestion. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins) seen in observations.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to have Jack Taylor around for a fun time, but doesn't mind Jacob Walker's absence. While Alexander White enjoyed watching the game at their favorite pub, The Crooked Billet, on May 14th, 2015, at 6:00 PM, they would have preferred if more friends were present. On May 15th, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Alexander White joined William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker for a relaxing outing at Victoria Park. That same day, the group is deciding where to watch the Luxembourg versus Israel game.

          Value
        • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alexander White wants to have Jack Taylor around for a fun time, but doesn't mind Jacob Walker's absence. While Alexander White enjoyed watching the game at their favorite pub, The Crooked Billet, on May 14th, 2015, at 6:00 PM, they would have preferred if more friends were present. On May 15th, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Alexander White joined William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker for a relaxing outing at Victoria Park. That same day, the group is deciding where to watch the Luxembourg versus Israel game.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet to the group.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he was devastated when his beloved grandfather passed away. He felt lost and alone, unsure how to navigate the world without his grandpa's steady presence. But, remembering his grandpa's words about finding joy in the simple things, Jacob gathered his friends and they spent the afternoon playing football in the park, their laughter echoing through the trees, a tribute to a life well-lived.

        • Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
          Prompt

        • Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"


          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of passive aggression, their every sentence dripping with veiled condescension and thinly veiled jabs, leaving you questioning your own sanity.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The King's Head and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group, but he can be unhappy if his friends don't all show up.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling down and recently spent time with friends at Victoria Park.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a socially awkward situation.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of those who did show up.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The King's Head to his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The King's Head to his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. All of William Jones's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, William Jones had a great time watching the game!

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan, I'll join you all later.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan, I'll join you all later.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan, I'll join you all later.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hi everyone, mind if I join you?
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hi everyone, mind if I join you?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
      Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan, I'll join you all later.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Sounds fun, I'll be there!"
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Sounds fun, I'll be there!"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
      Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan, I'll join you all later.
      Alexander White -- "Hi everyone, mind if I join you?


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Sounds fun, I'll be there!"

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only *decent* place to watch the game, you know.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only *decent* place to watch the game, you know.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
      Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
      Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
      Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a plan, I'll join you all later.
      Alexander White -- "Hi everyone, mind if I join you?
      Alice Lewis -- "Sounds fun, I'll be there!"


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only *decent* place to watch the game, you know.
    Active player

      Name

    • Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only *decent* place to watch the game, you know.
      Context for action selection and components
      • PersonBySituation

          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of those who did show up.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group, but he can be unhappy if his friends don't all show up.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of those who did show up.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be hoping that all of his friends will show up at the pub so they can enjoy the game together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a slightly melancholic mood and preparing to meet his friends for another soccer game viewing at The King's Head.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of those who did show up.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of passive aggression, their every sentence dripping with veiled condescension and thinly veiled jabs, leaving you questioning your own sanity.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The King's Head and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is meeting friends for a soccer game viewing at The King's Head pub later that evening. He seems to be tired and perhaps a bit down.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a slightly melancholic mood and preparing to meet his friends for another soccer game viewing at The King's Head.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of those who did show up.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only *decent* place to watch the game, you know.

    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]

He had practiced tirelessly, convinced he deserved a spot, and the rejection felt like a personal attack. From that day forward, he viewed every success of his teammates, particularly Jack Taylor who made the team, with a simmering resentment.

', "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.", "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.", "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.", "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable."]

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones is spending the afternoon with friends in Victoria Park before heading to a pub to watch the Andorra-Portugal football game. He is looking forward to watching the game with Alexander White and appreciates Jacob Walker's commentary.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

He had practiced tirelessly, convinced he deserved a spot, and the rejection felt like a personal attack. From that day forward, he viewed every success of his teammates, particularly Jack Taylor who made the team, with a simmering resentment.

          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The King's Head

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

She believes the game would be more fun if Jacob Walker was there.

          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to watch a game at a pub and doesn't mind if William Jones comes or not. She is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional. Alice Lewis is neutral on the matter of Jack Taylor being at the pub. She believes the game would be more fun if Jacob Walker was there.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of passive aggression, their every sentence dripping with veiled condescension and thinly veiled jabs, leaving you questioning your own sanity.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The King's Head and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited to watch the football game at a pub with his friends and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, and Jack Taylor.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely head to The King's Head pub to watch the game with his friends.

          Answer: The King's Head

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company, especially if the game gets tense.

          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to go to the pub with Jack Taylor to watch the game.

Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
          Answer: Considering the relationship between Jack Taylor and Alexander White, the quantified credibility is 0.8.

      • Observation

He hopes William Jones will be there so they can celebrate a win together and thinks the game would be more fun with Jack Taylor cheering along. He is indifferent to the presence of Alice Lewis and Jacob Walker.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion or suggestion. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins) seen in observations.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to watch the game at a pub with William Jones and Jack Taylor. He hopes William Jones will be there so they can celebrate a win together and thinks the game would be more fun with Jack Taylor cheering along. He is indifferent to the presence of Alice Lewis and Jacob Walker.

          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Crooked Billet

      Stage index

      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs
    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.

Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The King's Head

        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The King's Head to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely head to The King's Head pub to watch the game with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of those who did show up.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group, but he can be unhappy if his friends don't all show up.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.


          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of passive aggression, their every sentence dripping with veiled condescension and thinly veiled jabs, leaving you questioning your own sanity.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The King's Head and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see some friends there. He is particularly looking forward to seeing William Jones and Alice Lewis.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently on his way to a pub to watch a football game with some friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be hoping that all of his friends will show up at the pub so they can enjoy the game together.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The King's Head
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The King's Head
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The King's Head
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The King's Head.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "I heard The Red Lion has a great atmosphere for football matches.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, what pubs around here have good crowds for football?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The King's Head is always good for football. They have a big screen and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, obviously.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Have you guys considered The Crooked Billet? They have a great beer garden and usually show the games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great!
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, guys. I'm up for that.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game, you know. It's a shame we have to settle for second best.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we catch the game at The Crooked Billet again?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head it is then.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at the pub with friends, particularly Alexander White and Jacob Walker. They are somewhat indifferent to the presence of Alice Lewis and Jack Taylor.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The King's Head.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
